questions.text: A 25-year-old man comes to the office to be evaluated for right buttock pain for three months. The patient describes the pain as dull with intermittent radiation to the right thigh and leg. The pain increases with prolonged sitting. He is currently training for a marathon that requires downhill running. The patient does not have back pain, bowel or bladder symptoms, or trauma history. Past medical history is unremarkable. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates tenderness to palpation of the right buttock. Lower extremity strength is 5/5 bilaterally, and sensation is intact. Deep tendon reflexes are +2 bilaterally. Straight leg raise is positive on the right lower extremity. Forceful internal rotation at the hip with the thigh extended reproduces the pain. Plain radiographs and an MRI of the spine and pelvis are unremarkable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an insidious onset of unilateral buttock pain that radiates to the thigh and leg, aggravated by prolonged sitting. This, in combination with a positive Freibergs test (reproduction of pain with forceful internal rotation of the hip with the thigh extended), is suggestive of Piriformis syndrome.   

Piriformis syndrome refers to a musculoskeletal condition that results from compression of the sciatic nerve as it passes through the piriformis. Compression can result from shortening, hypertrophy, or spasm of the piriformis muscle secondary to trauma or overuse. Symptoms include pain in the buttock area, accompanied by sciatica-like pain, numbness, and weakness that traverses the back of the thigh, calf, and foot. Pain from piriformis syndrome is often worse when walking upstairs, after sitting, or while walking or running. Physical examination demonstrates tenderness in the sciatic notch and often with direct palpation over the piriformis.   

Option Analysis

❌ Lumbar spinal stenosis:
Incorrect: Lumbar spinal stenosis presents with neurogenic claudication (i.e. buttock and leg pain, discomfort, sensory loss, and weakness with walking, standing, or maintaining certain postures). This patient’s unilateral buttock pain exacerbated with sitting and tenderness to palpation at the buttocks is consistent with piriformis syndrome.
❌ L1 radiculopathy:
Incorrect: L1 radiculopathy results from intervertebral disc herniation at the L1 level. Symptoms involve pain, paresthesias, sensory loss in the inguinal region, and slight weakness with hip flexion. Unilateral buttock pain with a positive Freibergs test is suggestive of piriformis syndrome.
✅ Piriformis syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Femoroacetabular impingement:
Incorrect: Femoroacetabular impingement syndrome can result from abnormal contact between the anterior femoral head and the acetabular rim. Patients present with insidious onset of groin pain that worsens with activity. Symptoms are most noticeable after sitting with hips flexed to 90 degrees for a  prolonged period (e.g a plane ride). Buttock pain is less common, and plain radiographs can often identify the impingement.
❌ Iliotibial band syndrome:
Incorrect: Iliotibial band (ITB) syndrome refers to an overuse injury of the lateral knee that occurs primarily in runners. Patients describe the insidious onset of pain localized to the lateral femoral epicondyle.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the emergency department after a fall off a bicycle. The patient struck a pothole and landed directly on his left shoulder. Pain is reported over the anterior left shoulder, radiating up the neck and down the left arm. Parents at bedside report the patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any daily medications. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), heart rate is 106/min, blood pressure is 110/65 mmHg, respiratory rate is 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient appears uncomfortable but in no acute distress. Examination of the left shoulder reveals point tenderness at the acromioclavicular (AC) joint. The patient can flex and extend the elbow with minimal pain. Radial pulse is 2+, capillary refill is less than 2 seconds, and sensation is intact. Which of the following is the best next step in diagnosis?

choices.text: Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the left shoulder
Computed tomography (CT) of the left shoulder

questions.solution:
This pediatric patient presents after a fall directly onto the shoulder, with physical examination revealing point tenderness at the acromioclavicular (AC) joint. The differential diagnosis includes clavicle fracture, AC separation, rotator cuff injury, and proximal humerus fracture. The best next step in diagnosis is to obtain a plain radiograph of the left shoulder.         

In children with musculoskeletal injuries, a careful history and physical examination are often sufficient to formulate and prioritize a differential diagnosis. It is helpful to categorize injuries based on the mechanism (e.g., direct trauma, no clear trauma, overuse) to narrow the differential diagnosis. In patients with acute trauma and a clear mechanism of injury, focal bony tenderness may indicate an underlying fracture, while tenderness localized to a joint may suggest a sprain or joint separation. The physical examination should also assess for deformity, swelling, and ecchymosis.       

In these cases, plain radiographs of the affected bone and nearby joints are typically obtained to evaluate for fracture or dislocation. If these are negative, but clinical suspicion remains high, computed tomography (CT) may be used to identify occult fractures, while magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can evaluate for soft tissue injury. If there is concern for non-accidental trauma, a skeletal survey should be performed in patients under 60 months of age or those with limited communication abilities. Overuse injuries are often diagnosed clinically, with physical examination maneuvers aiding in identification. For example, a positive squeeze test of the calcaneus may support a diagnosis of Sever disease (calcaneal apophysitis).       

P.S. Physicians are mandatory reporters in cases of suspected child abuse and neglect in every U.S. state and territory. Visit www.childhelphotline.org for help, resources, and reporting information. You can also visit www.childwelfare.gov/state-child-abuse-and-neglect-reporting-numbers for U.S. state-specific reporting numbers.   

Option Analysis

✅ Radiograph of the left shoulder:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the left shoulder:
Incorrect: MRI is generally reserved for soft tissue injuries such as rotator cuff or labral tears. This patient’s presentation is consistent with acromioclavicular (AC) separation, which can be diagnosed with plain radiographs. 
❌ Computed tomography (CT) of the left shoulder:
Incorrect: CT of the left shoulder is not indicated unless there is concern for complex or occult fractures missed on plain radiographs. Acromioclavicular (AC) separation can be diagnosed with plain radiographs. 
❌ Arthrocentesis of the left shoulder:
Incorrect: Arthrocentesis is used in the evaluation of joint effusions in conditions such as septic or crystal-induced arthritis. It is not indicated in the setting of acute trauma without signs of joint effusion or infection. 
❌ Radiograph of the left humerus:
Incorrect: This patient can flex and extend at the elbow, with point tenderness at the acromioclavicular (AC) joint, consistent with AC separation. A radiograph of the left humerus may be obtained as a precaution given the location of injury, but a radiograph of the left shoulder will diagnose this patient’s AC separation.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after being struck by a car while crossing the street. Upon arrival, the child is awake, anxious, and pale, speaking in short phrases with a hoarse but intelligible voice. The child has a history of mild intermittent asthma and was hospitalized for bronchiolitis at age 2. Immunizations are up to date, and there are no known drug allergies or history of bleeding disorders. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), heart rate is 145/min, respiratory rate is 30/min, blood pressure is 88/56 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. There is moderate nasal bleeding but no obvious facial deformity. A large, bleeding laceration is present over the left thigh with brisk arterial bleeding. Capillary refill is 5 seconds. Peripheral pulses are weak but palpable. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Application of direct pressure to the bleeding site and intravenous (IV) access

questions.solution:
The primary survey in pediatric trauma follows the ABCDE sequence: Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure. This patient’s airway is currently patent, and breathing is adequate; however, there is evidence of circulatory compromise, including a large bleeding laceration, delayed capillary refill, and weak peripheral pulses. Hemorrhage control and IV access are immediate priorities to prevent progression to decompensated shock.

Additional measures may be required during the primary survey to stabilize a patient. Suction the oropharynx as needed and assess for airway obstruction, keeping in mind pediatric airways are narrower and more prone to collapse. Use pulse oximetry to assess oxygenation and provide bag-mask ventilation or intubation if respiratory effort is inadequate. Control external bleeding promptly, establish vascular access, and begin fluid resuscitation or transfusion if signs of shock are present.

The secondary survey is performed after the primary survey is complete and the patient has been stabilized. It involves obtaining a detailed history using the AMPLE mnemonic (Allergies, Medications, Past medical history, Last meal, and Events related to the trauma) and conducting a thorough head-to-toe physical examination to identify any injuries not detected during the primary survey. This phase may also include diagnostic imaging and laboratory tests to further evaluate injuries and guide ongoing management.

Option Analysis

❌ Bag-mask ventilation:
Incorrect: This patient is breathing spontaneously with adequate oxygen saturation and no signs of apnea or severe respiratory distress. Bag-mask ventilation is indicated for patients with inadequate respiratory effort or apnea, which is not present here.
✅ Application of direct pressure to the bleeding site and intravenous (IV) access:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Intubation:
Incorrect: Although the child has a hoarse voice, there is no stridor or visible airway obstruction. The ability to speak in short phrases and maintain oxygen saturation indicates that immediate intubation is not required at this time. Airway status should be monitored closely.
❌ Cervical spine radiographs:
Incorrect: While cervical spine imaging may be warranted in trauma, it is part of the secondary survey. It should not delay immediate management of life-threatening conditions such as an active hemorrhage.
❌ Full secondary survey:
Incorrect: The secondary survey is performed only after the primary survey is completed, and the patient is stabilized. Proceeding to a full secondary survey in this patient before addressing the ongoing hemorrhage risks further hemodynamic compromise.

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy presents to the emergency department for evaluation of right lower leg pain. The patient was pole-vaulting and fell awkwardly on the right leg. The patient heard a “pop” and experienced immediate, severe pain. Parents report that the child is otherwise healthy and does not take any daily medication. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), heart rate is 120/min, blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg, respiratory rate is 22/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient appears to be in severe pain. Examination of the right lower extremity reveals an obvious deformity with bone protruding through the anterior shin. Dorsalis pedis pulse is 2+, sensation is intact, and the child can move all toes. Intravenous access is established, and fentanyl is administered for pain. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Radiographs of the tibia and fibula

questions.solution:
This pediatric patient presents with a complete open fracture, likely of the tibia and fibula. Open fractures require immediate administration of intravenous antibiotics, copious wound irrigation, appropriate analgesia, and emergent orthopedic consultation to reduce the risk of infection and ensure timely surgical management.       

Pediatric musculoskeletal injuries encompass a wide range of conditions involving bones, joints, connective tissue, and muscles. While most injuries are related to low-energy trauma like falls or sports, severe injuries can result from high-energy trauma like motor vehicle accidents. Common pediatric musculoskeletal injuries include fractures, sprains, joint dislocations or subluxations, and overuse injuries.         

Initial management should include an Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, and Exposure (ABCDE) assessment, along with evaluation of joint stability and neurovascular status. Although most pediatric musculoskeletal injury patients are stable, certain injuries (e.g., pelvic, hip, and proximal femur fractures) can cause significant hemorrhage, requiring urgent surgical intervention. Other orthopedic emergencies include open fractures and injuries associated with nerve or vascular compromise.    

Option Analysis

✅ Intravenous cefazolin:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Radiographs of the tibia and fibula:
Incorrect: This patient has evidence of an open fracture of the lower extremity. While a radiograph is indicated to confirm the underlying diagnosis, antibiotic administration should not be delayed, as early antibiotics reduce the risk of infection.  
❌ Traction splint:
Incorrect: A traction splint is often utilized for femur fractures but is not appropriate for tibial or fibular fractures. Since this patient has an open fracture, initial management should focus on infection prevention. 
❌ Short leg splint:
Incorrect: A short leg splint is an appropriate method of immobilization for tibial fractures. However, before reduction and splint placement, the patient requires copious wound irrigation and intravenous antibiotic administration. 
❌ Bedside reduction of the fracture:
Incorrect: This patient has an open fracture that requires operative reduction in a controlled, sterile environment such as an operating room. Copious wound irrigation and intravenous antibiotic administration should be performed prior to further management.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents to her family medicine physician for a routine checkup after sustaining a right tibia fracture from a motor vehicle accident one month ago. She has been using crutches frequently for ambulation and endorses decreased sensation over her right dorsoradial arm and an inability to extend her right wrist, thumb, and fingers. The patient states that her symptoms subside with rest. Which of the following is most likely responsible for this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with findings of radial nerve compression (often known as “Saturday night palsy”).   Patients with this condition often have a history of persistent compression applied to the axilla, either by a physical object such as crutches or via prolonged abduction of the arm (e.g. falling asleep on an outstretched arm).

Patients with radial nerve compression often endorse absent or decreased sensation on the dorsoradial side of the hand and wrist, in addition to the inability to extend their wrist, thumb, and fingers. When the hand is placed in pronation, the wrist and hand will drop (a finding known as “wrist drop”)—approximately 92% of patients suffering from radial nerve compression resolve with observation alone.  

Option Analysis

❌ C7 nerve root injury  :
Incorrect: An isolated injury to the C7 nerve root is rare and low-yield for examination purposes. On rare occasions, injury to the C7 nerve root is associated with Erb palsy.  
❌ Carpal tunnel syndrome  :
Incorrect: This patient’s disease etiology and symptomatology are not congruent with findings of carpal tunnel syndrome, which presents with median nerve neuropathy most commonly in patients with underlying diabetes, hypothyroidism, or repetitive hand motions.  
✅ Radial nerve injury:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ulnar nerve injury  :
Incorrect: Ulnar nerve injury presents with an ulnar claw hand, rather than complete wrist drop as observed in this patient’s presentation.  
❌ C5-C6 nerve root injury  :
Incorrect: Upper brachial plexus injuries often occur from lateral flexion of the neck, causing partial or complete laceration of cervical nerve roots C5-6. Injury to these nerve roots results in Erb palsy, wherein the wrist is flexed, the forearm is extended, and the arm is internally rotated.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man comes to the office for evaluation of right foot pain. The patient describes the pain as “burning” and located on the sole of the foot and the toes. The pain radiates to the calf and is exacerbated by prolonged standing and running. The patient has not suffered any trauma to the right foot. The patient currently runs 10 to 20 miles daily for an upcoming marathon. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows pain with passive dorsiflexion and eversion of the right ankle. Sensation to light touch and pressure are reduced over the plantar surface of the right foot. Tapping posterior to the right medial malleolus produces a tingling, electric shock sensation. Deep tendon reflexes are within normal limits. Compression of which of the following nerves is the most likely etiology of this patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with a sharp, burning pain and reduced sensation over the sole of the feet and a positive Tinel sign (shock-like sensation on tapping the tibial nerve behind the medial malleolus), consistent with tarsal tunnel syndrome, secondary to the compression of tibial nerve.   

The tibial nerve is a branch of the sciatic nerve and traverses through the popliteal fossa and posterior compartment of the leg. It then enters the foot through the tarsal tunnel inferior and posterior to the medial malleolus where it innervates the plantar surface of the foot. Injury or compression of the tibial nerve at the tarsal tunnel results in sensory loss over the sole of the foot. Plantarflexion and inversion of the foot remains intact, as fibers innervating these muscles branch proximally to the tarsal tunnel. Common risk factors for tarsal tunnel syndrome include benign tumors/cysts, bone spurs, overuse injury, inflammation of the tendon sheath or swelling from a broken or sprained ankle.  

In contrast, injury to the nerve at the popliteal fossa (e.g., deep penetrating trauma or knee surgery) results in loss of plantar flexion, loss of flexion of toes and weakened inversion. Consequently, patients often present with feet held in the calcaneovalgus position (everted at rest with loss of inversion and plantar flexion).  



Option Analysis

❌ Femoral:
Incorrect: The femoral nerve can be compressed during prolonged maintenance in the dorsal lithotomy position or from pelvic fractures or hip dislocations. Patients present with sensory loss over the anterior thigh and medial leg, weakness of knee flexion and hip extension, and decreased patellar reflexes. A positive Tinel sign posterior to the medial malleolus is suggestive of tarsal tunnel syndrome.  
❌ Common peroneal:
Incorrect: Compression of the common peroneal nerve occurs at the proximal fibula due to prolonged hyperflexion of the knee or from leg casting. Sensory symptoms occur at the posterolateral leg and dorsolateral foot and are often associated with foot drop.   
✅ Tibial:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ilioinguinal :
Incorrect: The Ilioinguinal nerve provides innervation to the upper medial thigh and perineum. Injury to this nerve can occur during pelvic surgery, and presents with chronic suprapubic or groin pain. The ilioinguinal nerve does not innervate the sole of the foot.  
❌ Lateral femoral cutaneous nerve :
Incorrect: Injury or impingement of the lateral femoral cutaneous nerve results in decreased anterior and lateral thigh sensation. Women who wear tight clothes are especially predisposed to impingement of this nerve. A positive Tinel sign, posterior to the medial malleolus, is suggestive of tibial nerve compression.

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man presents to the emergency department to evaluate right wrist pain. The patient was playing pick-up basketball when he tripped, fell, and landed on an outstretched right hand. He states, “I thought I might have a wrist sprain, but my fourth and fifth fingers started feeling numb, so I came to the ED to get checked out.” He is otherwise healthy and does not take any medication. Physical examination reveals tenderness to palpation and swelling over the hypothenar eminence. The patient’s initial right hand and wrist radiographs are unremarkable. A carpal tunnel view of the right hand is subsequently obtained and shown below. Which of the following anatomic structures is at most significant risk of injury based on this patient’s clinical presentation?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents after a fall on an outstretched hand. He has pain over the ulnar aspect of the wrist and numbness of the fourth and fifth digits. The carpal tunnel view demonstrates a fracture to the hook of the hamate, which carries a risk of compression injury to the ulnar nerve as it passes through the Gunyon canal.

Hook of the hamate injuries are uncommon but typically occur due to a mechanism of injury involving a fall on an outstretched hand (“FOOSH” injury). Clinically, patients will experience pain and swelling over the ulnar aspect of the wrist and hypothenar eminence with associated ulnar nerve deficits if compression is present. Careful physical examination should be performed to assess ulnar nerve and artery function to ensure that neither is injured. This evaluation can be accomplished via 1) strength and sensation testing of the fourth and fifth digits and 2) pressing down on the radial artery and assessing if sufficient blood can reach the hand via the ulnar artery.

Hook of the hamate fractures are often missed on initial evaluation and misdiagnosed as wrist sprains, as frontal and lateral radiographs are often unremarkable.  A carpal tunnel view of the wrist can be obtained for further evaluation if suspicion remains despite normal radiographs.

Option Analysis

✅ Ulnar nerve  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Extensor digitorum  :
Incorrect: The extensor digitorum is located on the dorsal aspect of the hand. Injury to this structure can occur when a direct force is applied to a digit held in extension. In contrast, this patient sustained a fall onto an outstretched hand and has imaging that reveals a hook of the hamate fracture.  
❌ Median nerve:
Incorrect: Injury to the median nerve is unlikely to occur from the hook of the hamate fractures.  
❌ Radial nerve  :
Incorrect: Radial nerve injury does not typically occur with the hook of the hamate fractures. Instead, it more commonly occurs with humeral shaft fractures.  
❌ Radial artery  :
Incorrect: Radial artery injury does not typically occur in the setting of the hook of the hamate fractures.

questions.text:
A 57-year-old man presents to the emergency department after being found down outside a bar. Emergency medical services were called to the scene after several bystanders saw the person lying in the street. The patient is poorly responsive and unable to provide a history. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 24/min, blood pressure is 130/80 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 93% on room air. The patient’s speech is slurred, and he responds only to pain. Physical examination reveals scattered abrasions over the arms and legs and a 1 cm laceration over the right occiput. The patient is further noted to have swelling of the right hand. A radiograph of the right hand is obtained and shown below. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of injury associated with this injury?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Force applied to a clenched fist
Direct force to the fifth digit held in extension
Sudden hyperextension of the fifth digit held in flexion
Lateral force applied to the fifth digit

questions.solution:
This patient presents after being found down with right-hand swelling, scattered abrasions, and a head laceration. Given these findings, he was likely involved in a physical altercation. Imaging demonstrates a fracture of the distal end of the fifth metacarpal, which is consistent with a boxer fracture. The most common mechanism of action leading to this injury pattern is a direct force applied to a clenched fist.  

Boxer fractures are common and represent approximately 10% of all hand fractures. It is most commonly seen amongst boxers (hence the name), individuals involved in physical altercations, and athletes participating in contact sports (e.g., football, rugby). The most common mechanism of injury for this fracture involves axial pressure applied to the metacarpal bone when the fist is in a clenched position.

Clinically, patients with boxer fractures will often experience dorsal hand pain, swelling, and possible deformity over the fifth knuckle. Treatment is generally conservative and involves analgesia with closed reduction and placement in an ulnar gutter splint. Surgical referral is indicated for severe deformity or a high degree of displacement and angulation.

Option Analysis

✅ Force applied to a clenched fist  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Fall on an outstretched hand  :
Incorrect: Fall on an outstretched hand (FOOSH) represents the major mechanism of injury for many wrist pathologies, including scaphoid and distal radius fractures. However, this patient has a characteristic fracture of the fifth metacarpal, which is suggestive of a boxer fracture, most commonly caused by a direct force applied to a clenched fist.  
❌ Direct force to the fifth digit held in extension  :
Incorrect: A direct force to the fifth digit held in extension would result in a Mallet finger caused by rupture of the extensor tendon where it attaches to the distal phalanx. In contrast, this patient’s imaging shows a fracture of the fifth metacarpal bone.  
❌ Sudden hyperextension of the fifth digit held in flexion  :
Incorrect: This is the mechanism of action attributed to the Jersey finger, injuring the flexor digitorum profundus tendon as it crosses the distal interphalangeal joint. In contrast, this patient’s imaging shows a fracture of the fifth metacarpal bone.  
❌ Lateral force applied to the fifth digit  :
Incorrect: A lateral force applied to the fifth digit would likely result in a dislocation injury rather than a fracture.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man presents to the emergency department with acute left shoulder pain. The patient was lowering himself from a pullup at the gym when he suddenly felt a “pop” followed by acute pain in the anterior left shoulder. The patient has a history of left supraspinatus tendinopathy that was treated with physical therapy. The patient is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. Physical examination reveals ecchymosis, swelling, and tenderness over the anterior left deltoid. The patient's arm is pronated and flexed at the elbow to 90 degrees. The examiner attempts to supinate the arm against resistance, which elicits shoulder pain. A radiograph of the shoulder is demonstrated below:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Rupture of the long-head of the biceps brachii
Rupture of the short-head of the biceps brachii

questions.solution:
This patient presents with anterior shoulder pain after a load is applied during eccentric contraction of the biceps brachii. Physical examination demonstrates a positive Yergason test. In combination, these findings are consistent with tendinopathy of the long-head of the biceps brachii.

Tear or rupture of the long-head of the biceps brachii is associated with an eccentric force applied to a contracted biceps tendon. Patients often recall a “snap” or “pop” followed by ecchymosis, swelling, and pain immediately after the inciting mechanism of injury. Additionally, patients will often have a bulbous mass in the upper arm due to excessive retraction of the biceps muscle belly. This finding is known as a "Popeye deformity."

Specific examination findings may include a positive Yergason test, wherein pain is reproduced at the anterior shoulder when the patient attempts to supinate the arm against resistance after the examiner places the patient's arm in pronation and 90 degree flexion at the elbow. In addition, an exam maneuver known as the Speed test may also yield a positive test. In this exam, the patient's arm is extended in full supination with the shoulder flexed, and the patient is asked to elevate the arm against a resistive force; a positive test will produce the pain.  

Option Analysis

✅ Rupture of the long-head of the biceps brachii  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Supraspinatus tear  :
Incorrect: While this patient has a history of rotator cuff injury, physical examination demonstrates a positive Yergason test. This physical examination maneuver has a high specificity for biceps injury. In contrast, a supraspinatus injury would demonstrate a positive empty can test.  
❌ Subacromial bursitis  :
Incorrect: Subacromial bursitis falls into the category of rotator cuff impingement injuries and presents with chronic shoulder pain. Patients with subacromial bursitis will demonstrate limited active range of motion but preserved passive range of motion.  
❌ Acromioclavicular joint separation  :
Incorrect: Acromioclavicular joint separation most commonly occurs due to a direct force to the lateral aspect of the shoulder while the arm is held in adduction. Clinical features include swelling and pain over the lateral aspect of the shoulder. Radiography will show widening of the acromioclavicular joint.  
❌ Rupture of the short-head of the biceps brachii  :
Incorrect: Rupture of the short-head of the biceps brachii is less common than rupture of the long-head of the biceps brachii. A common mechanism of injury involves sudden forceful extension of the person's flexed elbow when the biceps muscle is fully contracted. Physical examination findings will demonstrate swelling of the antecubital fossa and a positive hook test.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a fall on an outstretched hand. During the fall, the patient hyperextended his right wrist and felt a “pop.” He is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals ecchymosis and swelling of the volar aspect of the right wrist. A lateral radiograph of the right wrist is obtained and shown below. Which of the following anatomic structures is at risk of injury based on this patient’s clinical presentation?  


Image reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons
questions.solution:
After a fall onto an outstretched hand (“FOOSH” injury), this patient presents with evidence of volar swelling and deformity. Imaging demonstrates the “spilled teacup” sign, pathognomonic for a lunate dislocation.

Lunate dislocations represent a relatively uncommon pattern of wrist injuries, but the most common mechanism of injury involves a FOOSH injury or high-energy trauma. The capitate stays in place in lunate dislocations, while the lunate is displaced. A closely related injury pattern is perilunate dislocation, in which the lunate stays, but the capitate is displaced.

Clinically, lunate dislocations present with pain on the volar-radial aspect of the wrist, with associated pain and swelling. Assessment of median nerve function is paramount in patients with this injury pattern, as lunate dislocations are often associated with compressive radiculopathy of the nerve. The most common radiographic feature associated with lunate dislocations is the spilled tea-cup sign on lateral x-rays, which represents the lunate being pushed off the radius into the palm.  

Option Analysis

✅ Median nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Radial nerve  :
Incorrect: Radial nerve injury does not typically occur with lunate dislocations. Instead, it more commonly occurs with humeral shaft fractures.  
❌ Ulnar nerve  :
Incorrect: Injury to the ulnar nerve more commonly occurs due to injury to the hook of the hamate, not the lunate.  
❌ Radial artery  :
Incorrect: Radial artery injuries are uncommon in the setting of lunate dislocations.  
❌ Ulnar collateral ligament  :
Incorrect: The ulnar collateral ligament is not typically damaged in the setting of lunate dislocations.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old man presents to the emergency department after sustaining an injury to the right middle finger. The patient was outside playing baseball with his friends when he sustained the injury. He is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 115/79 mmHg, and pulse is 102/min. Physical examination demonstrates an inability to extend the right middle finger's distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint. Flexion at the DIP joint of this digit is preserved. A picture of the patient’s hand is demonstrated below. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of injury associated with this pathology?  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia

choices.text: Direct force to the third digit held in extension
Lateral force applied to the third digit
Sudden hyperextension of the third digit held in flexion
Direct force applied to a clenched fist

questions.solution:
This patient presents with evidence of a mallet finger (baseball finger), which refers to an injury to the extensor digitorum as it crosses the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint. The most common mechanism of injury associated with this pathology is a direct force to the digit held in extension. This injury pattern results in an inability to extend the finger at the DIP joint.

Mallet finger is the most common closed tendon injury of the finger and is a common injury pattern in baseball players. The mechanism of injury involves a direct force to a digit held in extension, such as when a baseball strikes the distal end of the finger resulting in forced flexion of the DIP joint. Clinically, this manifests with pain and swelling over the dorsum of the DIP joint, DIP flexion deformity, and an inability to extend the DIP joint actively.

Treatment for a simple mallet finger (without an associated fracture) involves splinting the finger in extension for six to eight weeks. If left in flexion, the finger is more prone to developing osteoarthritis or a swan neck deformity. If the mallet finger is associated with a fracture, surgical referral, in addition to splinting, is indicated.

Option Analysis

✅ Direct force to the third digit held in extension  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lateral force applied to the third digit  :
Incorrect: A lateral force applied to the third digit would likely result in a dislocation injury, manifesting with difficulty both flexing and extending the affected joint.  
❌ Fall on an outstretched hand  :
Incorrect: Wrist pathologies (e.g., scaphoid fracture, distal radius fracture) can arise following a fall onto an outstretched hand (“FOOSH” injury). In contrast, this patient presents with drooping and an inability to extend the fingertip, which is more consistent with a mallet finger.  
❌ Sudden hyperextension of the third digit held in flexion  :
Incorrect: This mechanism of action will result in injury to the flexor digitorum profundus tendon as it crosses the distal interphalangeal joint. Patients with this injury pattern will extend, but not flex, the fingertip.  
❌ Direct force applied to a clenched fist  :
Incorrect: A direct force applied to a clenched fist will often fracture the fifth metacarpal. This fracture pattern is termed a boxer fracture. In contrast, this patient presents with drooping and an inability to extend the fingertip, which is more consistent with a mallet finger.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old woman presents to the emergency department to evaluate left wrist pain. The patient was cleaning the bathroom when she slipped, fell, and landed on an outstretched left arm. She was subsequently unable to move her left wrist due to pain. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, and she takes amlodipine daily. She does not smoke or consume alcohol. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates swelling and deformity of the left wrist. Plain films of the left wrist are shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?  

Image reproduced from Radiopedia.
questions.solution:
This older patient presents after a fall on an outstretched hand (“FOOSH” injury). Imaging of the wrist demonstrates a distal radius fracture with dorsal angulation, which is consistent with a Colles fracture.

Colles fractures are the most common wrist fracture and typically occur after sports-related injuries in younger patients or low-energy trauma in older patients with osteoporosis. A fracture will appear on plain films of the distal radius, with varying degrees of impaction, displacement, and associated intra-articular fractures. The most common mechanism of injury involves a fall on an outstretched hand, such that the direction of force displaces the radial fragment dorsally.

Smith fractures are distal radius fractures with volar angulation. The most common mechanism of injury for this fracture pattern is falling onto flexed wrists. This contrasts to Colles fractures, wherein the wrist is held in extension during the fall. Smith fractures can be diagnosed via plain films.

Clinically, both fracture patterns will demonstrate swelling and deformity of the wrist with limited passive and active range of motion due to pain. Assessment of neurovascular status should take place before and after closed reduction.  

Option Analysis

✅ Colles fracture:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Smith fracture:
Incorrect: A Smith fracture involves volar displacement of the distal radius fracture fragment. In contrast, this patient’s radiograph demonstrates dorsal displacement of the distal radius fracture fragment.  
❌ Galeazzi fracture  :
Incorrect: A Galeazzi fracture is a transverse dorsally displaced fracture of the mid-radius with subsequent widening of the distal radio-ulnar joint.  
❌ Monteggia fracture:
Incorrect: Monteggia fractures are ulnar fractures with associated dislocation of the radial head from its articulation with the capitellum.  
❌ Bennett fracture:
Incorrect: A Bennett fracture occurs at the base of the first metacarpal. It is an intraarticular fracture wherein the palmar ulnar aspect of the first metacarpal base is separated from the remainder of the first metacarpal.

questions.text:
A 52-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with worsening right shoulder pain. The patient has difficulty pulling items off the shelf and can no longer do overhead weight exercises. Additionally, the pain often wakes the patient from sleep at night, especially when she lies on the right shoulder. Past medical history is notable for hypertension. On physical examination, the shoulder and elbow are placed at 90 degrees of flexion in front of the body. The patient experiences pain when the examiner internally rotates the shoulder. The left shoulder has a full range of motion. There is no reproducible tenderness on palpation or flexion of the cervical spine. A radiograph of the right shoulder is shown below:  


Image reproduced from ">Wikimedia Commons  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with intermittent shoulder pain that worsens with overhead movements, but she has a normal shoulder radiograph. In addition, she has a positive Hawkins test, which is indicative of rotator cuff impingement or tendinopathy.

Rotator cuff impingement or tendinopathy is a common cause of shoulder pain. It often occurs due to repetitive overhead activity that results in inflammation of the rotator cuff tendons. Patients often describe pain over the lateral deltoid that is worse with overhead activity or while lying on the affected shoulder at night.

Physical examination will often demonstrate a positive Neer impingement test, wherein the patient experiences pain as the arm is passively flexed while in internal rotation. In addition, the Hawkins test can be used to diagnose rotator cuff impingement or tendinopathy. In this test, the examiner passively positions the shoulder and elbow at 90 degrees of flexion in front of the body, and patients will experience pain when the examiner passively internally rotates the shoulder.

Treatment of rotator cuff impingement or tendinopathy is centered on conservative management with physical therapy, analgesia, and rest.  

Option Analysis

✅ Rotator cuff tendinopathy  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Adhesive capsulitis  :
Incorrect: Adhesive capsulitis, also known as “frozen shoulder syndrome,” manifests with gross stiffness of the shoulder and nagging pain. Physical examination will demonstrate significant reductions in active and passive range of motion in two or more planes of movement.  
❌ Osteoarthritis  :
Incorrect: This patient’s above radiograph does not demonstrate evidence of glenohumeral joint space narrowing or bony erosion. Thus osteoarthritis is unlikely to be the cause of this patient’s symptoms.  
❌ Biceps tendinopathy  :
Incorrect: Biceps tendinopathy manifests with pain focused in the anterior shoulder with radiation distally over the biceps muscle.  
❌ Cervical spondylosis  :
Incorrect: Cervical spondylosis can mimic rotator cuff tendinopathy. However, in this condition, pain is often localized over the cervical spine, and patients can have a positive Spurling test (reproduction of symptoms when the patient’s head is turned towards the affected side, and pressure is applied to the top of the head).

questions.text:
A 72-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician with worsening left shoulder pain. The pain has been present for years, but she now is having difficulty writing on the chalkboard during her elementary school classes. The patient was a professional soccer player in her early adulthood, and she sustained a rotator cuff injury that was repaired surgically. Medical history is also notable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. On physical examination, the patient has marked tenderness to palpation at the glenohumeral joint and limited abduction and external rotation secondary to pain. A radiograph of the left shoulder is demonstrated below:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with chronic left shoulder pain and a limited range of motion due to pain. The patient’s radiograph demonstrates glenohumeral joint space narrowing, sclerosis, and osteophyte formation. These findings are consistent with glenohumeral osteoarthritis.

Glenohumeral osteoarthritis is a relatively uncommon form of osteoarthritis. However, it more commonly occurs in older females with a history of prior shoulder surgery, injury, or trauma. Conditions that predispose to glenohumeral osteoarthritis include shoulder dislocation, rotator cuff tears, rheumatoid arthritis, and humeral head/neck fracture.

Most cases of glenohumeral osteoarthritis present clinically with chronic, nagging, and deep shoulder pain that is exacerbated with movement. Shoulder mobility is typically limited due to pain, especially during abduction and external rotation. Treatment involves analgesia and shoulder replacement surgery in advanced cases of the disease.  

Option Analysis

✅ Glenohumeral osteoarthritis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Osteosarcoma  :
Incorrect: Osteosarcoma arises from pleomorphic osteoid producing cells and presents as a painful mass or pathologic fracture. Radiographic features include lytic bone lesions and a sunburst pattern, which is secondary to aggressive periosteal reaction.  
❌ Supraspinatus tendinopathy  :
Incorrect: While this patient has a history of rotator cuff injury, the physical examination and radiograph are more consistent with glenohumeral osteoarthritis.  
❌ Cervical spondylosis  :
Incorrect: Cervical spondylosis can mimic disorders of the glenohumeral joint. However, in this condition, pain is more often localized over the cervical spine. In addition, patients with cervical spondylosis may have a positive Spurling test (in which symptoms are reproduced when the patient’s head is turned towards the affected side, and pressure is applied to the top of the head).  
❌ Adhesive capsulitis  :
Incorrect: Adhesive capsulitis, also known as “frozen shoulder syndrome,” manifests with gross stiffness of the shoulder and nagging pain. Physical examination will demonstrate significant reductions in active and passive range of motion in two or more planes of movement. It can be differentiated from osteoarthritis as early disease typically demonstrates a normal shoulder radiograph (unlike that of this patient) and presents subacutely over the course of days to weeks (whereas this patient’s symptoms are chronic).

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man presents to the emergency department with left-sided shoulder pain. The patient was playing flag football when he tripped and fell on an outstretched left arm. Physical examination is notable for a gap along the lateral edge of the left acromion process. The left arm is in slight abduction and external rotation. A radiograph of the shoulder is obtained and shown below:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with acute onset shoulder pain after falling on an outstretched arm. Physical examination is notable for a visible deformity of the left shoulder, and radiography demonstrates an anteriorly displaced glenohumeral head on the axillary Y-view. These findings are consistent with an anterior shoulder dislocation.

Anterior shoulder dislocations are a common orthopedic injury and typically occur after a fall onto an outstretched arm. Clinically, patients may present with a visible deformity of the shoulder and a “squared appearance” compared to the contralateral shoulder. In addition, patients will typically hold their arm in slight abduction and external rotation. Radiographs will demonstrate an anteriorly displaced humeral head on the axillary Y-view.

Complications include axillary artery and nerve injury. As a result, patients should be assessed for neurovascular injury both pre- and post-reduction. In addition, associated bony injuries to the glenohumeral joint include the Hill-Sachs deformity (posterolateral humeral head compression fracture) and Bankart lesions (injury to the inferior glenoid labrum).

In contrast, posterior shoulder dislocations are rare and most commonly occur due to prolonged seizures, high speed motor vehicle accidents, or lightning injuries. Clinically, they are less commonly associated with a gross deformity. However, patients may demonstrate prominence of the coracoid process or posterior shoulder. In addition, the arm is often held in internal rotation. Complications include rotator cuff/labrum tears and humeral fractures.  

Option Analysis

✅ Anterior glenohumeral joint dislocation  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Posterior glenohumeral joint dislocation  :
Incorrect: Posterior shoulder dislocations are rare but can occur in the setting of high speed motor vehicle accidents, status epilepticus, and lightning injuries. It will demonstrate a posteriorly displaced humeral head on the axillary Y-view. In contrast, this patient’s shoulder radiograph demonstrates an anteriorly displaced humeral head.  
❌ Inferior glenohumeral joint dislocation  :
Incorrect: Inferior glenohumeral joint dislocations occur due to axial loading while the arm is fully abducted. Patients will have their arm fully abducted with the elbow flexed above their head. Plain films will demonstrate the humeral head inferior to the glenoid.  
❌ Sternoclavicular joint separation  :
Incorrect: Sternoclavicular joint separation involves a tear in the sterno-clavicular ligaments and is classified as either anterior or posterior. This radiograph does not capture the sterno-clavicular joint.  
❌ Superior glenohumeral joint dislocation  :
Incorrect: Superior glenohumeral joint dislocations are a rare occurrence and are due to a force in the anterior and superior direction.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a bicycle accident. The primary survey is unremarkable and secondary survey is notable for scattered abrasions over the face and chest wall. There is marked tenderness to palpation over the right mid-clavicle with overlying ecchymosis and crepitus. The patient has 2+ pulses in the right upper extremity and is otherwise neurovascularly intact. A radiograph of the right shoulder is demonstrated below:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia  
Which of the following is the next best step in management of this patient’s clinical condition?

choices.text: CT-angiogram of the right upper extremity

questions.solution:
This patient presents with tenderness to palpation over the mid-clavicle with overlying ecchymosis and crepitus. The radiograph demonstrates a fracture of the mid-clavicle, which should be managed conservatively with analgesics and placement in a shoulder sling.

Clavicle fractures are a common injury, with a predilection towards affecting males and young children. In fact, it is the most commonly fractured bone in pediatric patients. Most injuries occur due to a direct force applied to the lateral aspect of the shoulder as a result of a fall, sporting injury, or motor vehicle collision. The most common area of fracture is the middle third of the clavicle, which accounts for approximately 80% of all clavicle fractures.

Clinically, most fractures will demonstrate swelling, ecchymosis, and tenderness over the site of fracture. Associated features may include crepitus or visible deformity, depending on the degree of displacement. The majority of clavicle fractures are managed nonoperatively via placement in a shoulder sling with adequate analgesia and orthopedic referral. Indications for surgical management include open fractures, neurovascular compromise, and tenting of the skin.  

Option Analysis

✅ Shoulder sling  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Open reduction and internal fixation  :
Incorrect: Open reduction and internal fixation is rarely indicated in the management of clavicle fractures. Indications for surgical repair include open fractures, neurovascular compromise, and tenting of the skin.  
❌ Shoulder spica splint  :
Incorrect: Shoulder spica splints are most commonly used for temporary immobilization of the shoulder or elbow following open or closed fracture reduction. They are not indicated in the management of clavicular fractures that are non-operative.  
❌ Figure of eight sling  :
Incorrect: Figure of eight slings were historically recommended for clavicle fractures. However, they are no longer recommended.  
❌ CT-angiogram of the right upper extremity  :
Incorrect: This patient is without evidence of neurovascular compromise, making a CT-angiogram of the right upper extremity of limited utility.

questions.text: A 36-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with worsening left shoulder pain. The patient is an avid weightlifter. However, over the past several months, he has experienced worsening left shoulder pain that is exacerbated by overhead movements. He has no history of major trauma or surgery. On physical examination, the patient has weakness in the left shoulder after downward pressure is applied while both arms are at 90° elevation in the scapular plane with full internal rotation. Which of the following anatomic structures is most likely to be disrupted given this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with left shoulder pain that is exacerbated by overhead activities. There is reproducible weakness with the empty can test. These findings are consistent with rotator cuff injury. The most commonly injured rotator cuff muscle is the supraspinatus.

The rotator cuff muscles include the supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, and subscapularis. These muscles coordinate complex movements of the shoulder joint and are commonly injured in athletes as well as older adults, resulting in a rotator cuff injury. The etiology of injury is often multifactorial and often stems from repetitive movements against resistance, rather than a single episode of trauma or injury to the shoulder.

The majority of rotator cuff injuries involve the supraspinatus, which is responsible for abduction of the arm. Patients often describe nagging pain localized to the deltoid that worsens with overhead movements. If a full thickness tear is present, patients may have weakness or an inability to raise the arm overhead.

The empty can test (also termed Jobe test) has a high specificity for supraspinatus injuries. In this test, the patient is placed in a standing or sitting position, and the arm is raised parallel to the ground in the scapular plane with the arm rotated to full internal rotation. Once rotated, the clinician pushes down on either the wrist or elbow, and the patient is instructed to resist the downward pressure. Weakness or pain in the tested shoulder elicits a positive test.  

Option Analysis

✅ Supraspinatus  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Subscapularis  :
Incorrect: While the subscapularis muscle is a part of the rotator cuff muscle group, it is less commonly injured than the supraspinatus muscle. The patient has an abnormal empty can test, which is more consistent with the presentation of a supraspinatus tear.  
❌ Infraspinatus  :
Incorrect: The infraspinatus is less commonly injured than the supraspinatus. In addition, this patient has an abnormal empty can test, which is more consistent with the presentation of a supraspinatus tear.  
❌ Teres minor  :
Incorrect: The teres minor is less commonly injured than the supraspinatus. In addition, this patient has an abnormal empty can test, which is more consistent with the presentation of a supraspinatus tear.  
❌ Biceps brachii  :
Incorrect: The biceps brachii is not a part of the rotator cuff muscle group.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old woman presents to the emergency department to evaluate right wrist pain. The patient was outside skateboarding when she fell directly onto an outstretched right hand. The pain is primarily in the radial aspect of the wrist. She is otherwise healthy and does not take any medications. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination is notable for tenderness to palpation over the radial fossa on the dorsal aspect of the hand. An initial radiograph of the right wrist is demonstrated below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Follow up radiograph in one week
Placement in the ulnar gutter splint

questions.solution:
This patient presents after a fall on an outstretched hand (“FOOSH”) with reproducible pain in the anatomic snuffbox on physical examination – which is concerning for a scaphoid fracture. In patients with this injury, nearly 25% will have normal radiographs on initial presentation and thus should undergo repeat imaging in one week to assess for a fracture pattern.

The scaphoid is the most commonly injured carpal bone and accounts for nearly 70% of fractured carpal bones. The most common mechanism of injury involves a fall onto an outstretched hand (“FOOSH”), which leads to hyperextension of the wrist and axial loading. Clinically, patients will experience pain at the radial aspect of the wrist, with swelling or reproducible tenderness to palpation at the anatomic snuffbox. 

Diagnosis of scaphoid fractures remains challenging, as many initial radiographs are negative, leading to the underdiagnosis of occult fractures. Thus any patient with a suspected scaphoid fracture should undergo repeat imaging in one week to assess for fracture. When a fracture pattern is present, it will typically manifest as a lucent line across the waist of the scaphoid and possible displacement of the fracture fragments.

If undiagnosed, patients with scaphoid fractures are at an increased risk of avascular necrosis of the scaphoid due to its tenuous blood supply from two different branches of the radial artery. Ultimately, avascular necrosis can result in debilitating pain, wrist deformity, and premature osteoarthritis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Follow up radiograph in one week  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Percutaneous screw fixation  :
Incorrect: Percutaneous screw fixation is the most common method of surgical repair for scaphoid fractures. This patient does not have definitive radiographic evidence of a fracture pattern. As a result, surgical intervention would be inappropriate at the moment.  
❌ Closed reduction:
Incorrect: Closed reduction is not typically performed in the setting of a scaphoid injury.  
❌ CT-angiography of the upper extremity  :
Incorrect: While the proximal end of the scaphoid is at risk for avascular necrosis, CT-angiography is generally not helpful in assessing scaphoid injuries.  
❌ Placement in the ulnar gutter splint  :
Incorrect: Patients with scaphoid injuries should be placed in a thumb spica splint, not an ulnar gutter splint.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after sustaining a hand injury. The patient was jogging when he tripped and fell onto an area of concrete with scattered glass shards. He sustained lacerations to the left hand. He is otherwise healthy and does not take medications. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 115/78 mmHg, and pulse is 103/min. Visual inspection of the left hand demonstrates a 4 cm laceration extending from the base of the hypothenar eminence to the thenar eminence. Which of the following should be evaluated to assess for underlying nerve injury?

choices.text: Sensation to the first, second, and third digits
Sensation to the medial fourth digit and entire fifth digit

questions.solution:
This patient sustained a laceration to the palm, which may lead to injury to the recurrent branch of the median nerve that travels superficially in the palm. Among the physical examination maneuvers listed, assessment of active thumb abduction is paramount in evaluating for potential injury to the recurrent branch of the median nerve.

Assessment of hand motor and sensory function after an injury is essential for appropriate treatment, disposition, and follow-up. All patients should undergo an assessment of strength, radial, ulnar, and digital pulses characterization, and a sensory examination. Patients with evidence of deficits should be assessed for associated tendinous, vascular, or nerve injury and, if discovered, should undergo consultation with a hand surgeon.

The median nerve provides sensation to the palmar aspect of the first, second, third, and half of the fourth digit. In addition, the nerve provides motor innervation to muscles in the thenar eminence and flexor muscles of the hand and wrist.

Injury to the recurrent branch of the median nerve will manifest with pure motor deficits, as it innervates the three muscles of the thenar eminence: the abductor pollicis brevis, opponens pollicis, and the superficial head of the flexor pollicis brevis. 

Option Analysis

✅ Active thumb abduction  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Sensation to the first, second, and third digits  :
Incorrect: This patient sustained a laceration of the palm, which can result in injury to the recurrent branch of the median nerve. If the nerve is injured, patients will develop motor dysfunction without sensory deficits.  
❌ Active extension of the digits  :
Incorrect: Extension of the digits of the hand is mediated via the radial nerve, which courses on the dorsal aspect of the hand, not the palmar aspect.  
❌ Sensation to the medial fourth digit and entire fifth digit  :
Incorrect: This patient sustained a laceration of the palm, which can result in injury to the recurrent branch of the median nerve. Sensation to these digits is mediated by the ulnar nerve, not the median nerve.  
❌ Active extension of the wrist  :
Incorrect: Extension of the wrist is mediated by the radial nerve, which courses on the dorsal aspect of the wrist, not the palmar aspect of the hand.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old boy presents to the emergency department after sustaining a shoulder injury while playing football. The patient was diving towards the end-zone when another player collided directly with his left shoulder. On physical examination, the patient is holding the left arm adducted. Swelling is present over the lateral aspect of the left shoulder. A radiograph of the left shoulder is demonstrated below:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia  
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with lateral shoulder pain after a direct blow to the acromioclavicular joint. The radiograph demonstrates widening of the acromioclavicular joint, which is consistent with acromioclavicular joint separation.

Acromioclavicular joint separation is a common injury. It is most often seen in young males engaged in bicycle accidents or high impact sports such as football. The most common mechanism of injury occurs due to a direct blow to the lateral aspect of the shoulder while the arm is held in adduction.

Clinical features include swelling and tenderness to the lateral aspect of the shoulder. A physical examination maneuver known as the crossover test, wherein passive cross-body adduction of the arm compresses the acromioclavicular joint, may elicit pain. Radiography will demonstrate widening of the acromioclavicular joint, superior displacement of the clavicle, and widening of the coracoclavicular ligament.

Injuries to the acromioclavicular joint are classified based on the degree of damage sustained by the acromioclavicular and coracoclavicular ligaments. In general, most injuries are managed nonoperatively via placement in a sling and immobilization.  

Option Analysis

✅ Acromioclavicular separation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Sternoclavicular separation  :
Incorrect: Sternoclavicular joint separations will often demonstrate a deformity and swelling along the medial aspect of the clavicle. They are more often anterior and without significant complications. Posterior dislocations are associated with increased morbidity due to their propensity to disrupt vascular structures.  
❌ Posterior shoulder dislocation  :
Incorrect: Posterior shoulder dislocations are rare but can occur in the setting of high speed motor vehicle accidents, status epilepticus, and lightning injuries. Plain films will demonstrate a posteriorly displaced humeral head on the axillary Y-view.  
❌ Anterior shoulder dislocation  :
Incorrect: Anterior shoulder dislocations are the most common form of shoulder dislocation and present with a squared-off appearance of the shoulder. The dislocated arm is typically in slight abduction and external rotation. The axillary Y-view will demonstrate an anteriorly placed humeral head relative to the glenoid fossa.  
❌ Clavicle fracture  :
Incorrect: There is no evidence of a left clavicle fracture on this patient’s radiograph.

questions.text:
A 44-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with worsening left shoulder pain. He can no longer do bench presses or shoulder presses at the gym due to weakness and pain. The pain is primarily located over the lateral shoulder, is worse at night, and is preventing him from obtaining adequate rest. Past medical history is otherwise unremarkable. He has no history of recent trauma or surgeries to the left shoulder. The patient subsequently undergoes a MRI of the left shoulder, which reveals the following:  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia  
Which of the following physical examination maneuvers is most likely to yield a positive test, given this patient’s clinical findings?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with worsening left shoulder pain and weakness. MRI imaging demonstrates a complete tear of the supraspinatus tendon. Of the physical examination techniques listed, the one most likely to demonstrate a positive finding is the empty can test.

The shoulder is made up of the rotator cuff muscles, the glenohumeral and acromioclavicular ligaments, and connective tissue. In the assessment of shoulder pain, several tests can aid in the diagnosis of a specific injury. For instance, the empty can test (also termed Jobe test) has a high specificity for supraspinatus injuries. In this test, the patient is placed in a standing or sitting position, and the arm is raised parallel to the ground in the scapular plane and fully internally rotated. Once rotated, the clinician pushes down on either the wrist or elbow, and the patient is instructed to resist the downward force. Weakness or pain in the tested shoulder represents a positive test result.

Another test known as the full can test also assesses for supraspinatus instability. It is performed in the same manner as the empty can test, with the only difference being that the patient's arms are not rotated to full internal rotation (e.g. thumbs are up).

Additional tests include the Neer test and Hawkins-Kennedy test, which assess for subacromial impingement syndrome. The Scarf test assesses for stability of the acromioclavicular joint and is commonly positive with partial or full tears of the acromioclavicular or coracoclavicular ligaments.  

Option Analysis

✅ Empty can test  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Lift off test  :
Incorrect: The lift off test is performed to assess for instability of the subscapularis. In this test, the patient actively lifts the dorsum of the hand off the back with resistance. This patient instead has evidence of a complete tear of the supraspinatus tendon.  
❌ Scarf test  :
Incorrect: The Scarf test is used to assess for stability of the acromioclavicular joint. It is performed by passively adducting the patient's arm across the body horizontally, approximating the elbow to the contralateral shoulder. This patient instead has evidence of a complete tear of the supraspinatus tendon.  
❌ Neer test  :
Incorrect: The Neer test is used to assess for subacromial impingement syndrome. This test is performed by stabilizing the patient's scapula with one hand and passively flexing the arm while it is internally rotated. This patient instead has evidence of a complete tear of the supraspinatus tendon.  
❌ Yergason test  :
Incorrect: The Yergason test is used to assess for tear or rupture of the long-head of the biceps brachii. In this test, pain is reproduced at the anterior shoulder as the patient attempts to supinate the arm against resistance when the arm is pronated and flexed at the elbow to 90 degrees. This patient instead has evidence of a complete tear of the supraspinatus tendon.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old man presents to the emergency department following a right knee injury. The patient was playing rugby when an opposing teammate tackled him. He felt a “pop” in the right knee and experienced pain after that. The patient is otherwise healthy. Physical examination demonstrates a large right knee effusion, a positive anterior drawer test, and a positive valgus stress test. Vital signs are within normal limits. An MRI of the patient's right knee is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely mechanism of injury that resulted in this patient’s condition?
 

Image reproduced from Radiopedia

choices.text: Posteriorly directed force on a flexed knee
Varus force applied to the knee
Direct force to the anterior knee

questions.solution:
After being tackled during a rugby match, this patient presents with right knee pain. Physical examination demonstrates positive anterior drawer and valgus stress tests, which are consistent with anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) and medial collateral ligament (MCL) tears respectively. MRI imaging not only reveals these findings but also evidence of meniscal injury with hyperintensity of the medial meniscus. In combination, these injuries constitute the unhappy triad or a “blown knee”.

The unhappy triad is defined as soft tissue injury to the ACL, MCL, and medial meniscus. This injury pattern is typical in contact sports (e.g., rugby, football, hockey) and occurs when the knee sustains a lateral blow while the foot is planted on the ground. Ultimately, this scenario produces an abduction and external rotation mechanism of injury.

Physical examination findings will often include joint effusion and pain with weight bearing.Injury to the ACL can be detected with a positive anterior drawer test, and MCL injury is associated with a positive valgus stress test. Meniscal injuries are often more challenging to detect, a positive McMurray test may be seen. Definitive diagnosis is achieved with MRI where all three injuries can be visualized. Most unhappy triad injuries are treated with surgical repair.  

Option Analysis

✅ Lateral force to the knee:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Posteriorly directed force on a flexed knee:
Incorrect: Posterior cruciate ligament injuries are rare and most commonly occur after high-force trauma with a posteriorly directed force on a flexed knee as in dashboard injuries.  
❌ Varus force applied to the knee:
Incorrect: Varus force applied to the knee from a high energy blow to the anteromedial knee which combines hyperextension and extreme varus force typically causes a lateral collateral ligament injury.  
❌ Twisting force at the knee:
Incorrect: Meniscus tears are often produced by a twisting mechanism applied to the knee, such as when turning rapidly or landing from a large jump.  
❌ Direct force to the anterior knee:
Incorrect: This is the most common mechanism of injury in the setting of patellar fractures. Contraction of the quadriceps aids in stabilizing the anterior and posterior ligaments of the knee.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after a motor vehicle collision. He was the restrained driver that skidded on ice hitting a tree at 50 miles per hour (80 kilometers per hour). In the emergency department the patient has an x-ray of the lower extremities that reveals a comminuted left tibial fracture. After a prolonged emergency surgery, the patient is admitted to the intensive care unit. The next day, he endorses severe left leg pain unresponsive to several rounds of intravenous morphine. The patient further endorses a pins and needles sensation and pain with movement in the left lower extremity. Temperature is 36.5°C (97.7°F), pulse is 105/min, respirations are 19/min and blood pressure is 100/60 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates tense, swollen and an exquisitely tender left calf with loss of sensation between the first and second toes. The overlying skin is shiny and cool to the touch. The patient has 2+ dorsalis pedis pulse in the left lower extremity. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Place the leg in balanced traction
Elevate the leg and apply ice packs
Obtain doppler ultrasonography of the lower extremity

questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation of excruciating leg pain following tibial fracture repair, worsened with passive leg movements, in combination with sensory loss, tense compartments, and cool extremities is consistent with compartment syndrome (CS).   

CS is an orthopedic emergency that commonly results from direct trauma (e.g. long bone fracture) or prolonged compression of an extremity but may also occur following revascularization of an acutely ischemic limb.  

CS typically involves significant swelling within a compartment of an injured extremity that compromises blood flow to the limb muscles and nerves.  

Signs and symptoms can be remembered as the six Ps:  



Pain with passive stretch of the affected muscles is the earliest symptom, followed by paresthesias ( pins and needle sensations), that can progress to neurologic deficits (e.g., loss of sensation and muscle weakness). Pallor and poikilothermia result from arterial occlusion and is uncommon. Arterial pulses are present in the majority of the patients.  

Diagnosis can be confirmed by measuring compartment pressures. Compartment pressures of >30-40 mmg are highly suggestive of CS. In addition, a value known as the delta pressure is often obtained, which is calculated by subtracting the compartment pressure from the patient’s diastolic blood pressure. Values less than 30 are consistent with CS. In high-risk patients (e.g., sensory loss and cool extremities), it can be diagnosed on clinical grounds alone. Time to fasciotomy is the most critical prognostic factor and should be performed immediately.  

Option Analysis

❌ Place the leg in balanced traction:
Incorrect: Traction can precipitate the development of compartment syndrome (CS). In patients with suspected CS, all external pressures on the compartment (e.g., dressing, splint, cast, or other restrictive covering) should be removed.   
❌ Obtain a lower extremity arteriogram:
Incorrect: A Lower extremity arteriogram provides detailed arterial mapping and is helpful when preparing for revascularization. This patient has a 2+ dorsalis pedis pulse.   
✅ Operative fasciotomy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Elevate the leg and apply ice packs:
Incorrect: The limb should neither be elevated nor placed in a dependent position. Placing the limb level with the heart helps to avoid reductions in arterial inflow and increases in compartment pressures from dependent swelling, both of which can exacerbate limb ischemia.  
❌ Obtain doppler ultrasonography of the lower extremity:
Incorrect: Doppler ultrasound of lower extremity is used for the diagnosis of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) as well arterial insufficiency. Although DVT can present with increasing pain and swelling, the onset is usually insidious and less severe. This patient’s clinical findings are more consistent with compartment syndrome.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after being stabbed in the right arm. Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 110/65 mm Hg. Physical examination demonstrates a 2 cm stab wound over the medial aspect of the cubital fossa with ongoing brisk, pulsatile bleeding. Neurologic examination demonstrates loss of sensation over the thenar eminence and dorsal and palmar aspects of the lateral 3 1⁄2 fingers. The patient also exhibits inability to flex the joints of the thumb, second and third digits, and inability to pronate the forearm. Injury to which of the following vascular structures is responsible for this patient’s ongoing bleeding?
questions.solution:
This patient’s stab wound is consistent with injury to the brachial artery and the median nerve, which lie next to each other in the cubital fossa. The cubital fossa contains four main vertical structures (lateral to medial): the radial nerve, biceps brachii tendon, brachial artery, and median nerve.   

The axillary artery terminates beyond the teres major's lower margin as it continues down the ventral surface of the arm to become the brachial artery. Once the brachial artery reaches the cubital fossa, it branches into the radial and ulnar arteries. Injury to the brachial artery  at the medial cubital fossa results in pulsatile, brisk bleeding, often with hematoma formation. Associated median nerve injury is common.    

In addition, the cubital fossa is a common site for venous blood sampling and intravenous line placement  due to its prominent and easily accessible veins. The most commonly accessed vein in this region is the median cubital vein, which connects the basilic and cephalic veins and lies superficial to the bicipital aponeurosis.  



Option Analysis

❌ Radial artery:
Incorrect: The brachial artery bifurcates at the inferior portion of the cubital fossa into the radial artery (superficial) and ulnar artery (deeper). The radial artery accompanies the superficial branch of the radial nerve in the forearm. This patient has evidence of median nerve injury, which lies close to the brachial artery in the medial aspect of the cubital fossa.  
✅ Brachial artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ulnar artery:
Incorrect: The brachial artery bifurcates at the inferior portion of the cubital fossa into the radial artery (superficial) and ulnar artery (deeper). The radial artery accompanies the superficial branch of the radial nerve in the forearm. This patient has evidence of median nerve injury, which lies close to the brachial artery in the medial aspect of the cubital fossa.  
❌ Deep brachial artery:
Incorrect: The deep brachial artery courses posterior to the humerus and is vulnerable to injury with proximal humeral fractures (e.g. humeral shaft fracture).  
❌ Anterior interosseous artery:
Incorrect: The anterior interosseous artery originates in the forearm distal to the cubital fossa.

questions.text: A 26-year-old man is brought to the emergency department to be evaluated for severe posterior right thigh pain. He experienced sudden right posterior thigh pain with an associated popping sound while performing a high-kick during martial arts practice. He is unable to bear weight on his right leg. The pain is constant and does not radiate. The patient does not have associated back or buttock pain. Past medical history is noncontributory. Vitals are within normal limits. Physical examination shows swelling and tenderness at the posterior thigh with surrounding ecchymosis. Musculoskeletal examination reveals limited knee flexion and hip extension on the right side. Sensation of the lower extremities is intact, and deep tendon reflexes are +2 bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with sudden onset of posterior thigh pain following a high kick which involves forced flexion at the hip with the knee and hip in extension. These findings suggest the patient has most likely suffered a hamstring tear due to an injury of the biceps femoris.  

Hamstring injuries classically occur during high-speed running and following low-speed mechanisms that involve stretching the hip and knee joints at their end ranges of motion. Hamstring strains are classified as either a pull (grade I), partial tear (grade II), or complete tear (grade III). Patients often present with sudden onset, minimal to severe pain over the posterior thigh, sometimes with an associated “popping” sound. Swelling and ecchymosis of the posterior thigh more commonly occur with complete tears. Physical examination demonstrates tenderness, loss of motion, and decreased strength with isometric contraction.
